item.title: Inside the Vic Debsoc website
item.description: Zero cost, low maintenance static sites for the non-technical

div.p: A while back I took it upon myself to design a new website for my debating society. I had a number of constraints that I know others have, and I think Iâ€™ve found the best solution, at time of writing.

li.p: Low technical complexity for authors. For most members of the society they have never heard of git. So it needs to have something like a WYSIWYG editor.

Low Cost. This is for a cash strapped charity, there are other, more important places to spend the money. In the end I was able to make it free to run, which is extra good as it saves the treasurer time.
Low technical complexity. Iâ€™m not going to be around forever, and I donâ€™t want for whoever takes over to have a huge maintenance burden.

div.p: Luckily this is a fairly small website, and modern tools have made this easy. The stack consists of Gitlab Pages, Hugo, and StaticCMS. If you just want to see an example you can find the repo here. All of these tools are open source, which should make any future migrations substantially easier.

The obvious solution in this space is GitHub Pages, and thatâ€™s what I use for this website. But one of the needs of StaticCMS is an authorisation. The details are beyond this post (and me), but whatâ€™s important is that GitHub doesnâ€™t support PKCE for OAuth apps. That means Iâ€™d need to rely on an external service like Netlify identity to handle the login flow. Thatâ€™s an unattractive solution due to the extra complexity. Fortunately, Gitlab does support it. Gitlab provides all the other services of GitHub, so it was an easy replacement.
I have found GitLabâ€™s time to first byte to be higher than Githubâ€™s, but that may just be a consequence of living in NZ.

Iâ€™ve tried other static site generators in the past, but I havenâ€™t found any as easy or powerful as Hugo. It also has a lot of useful features like minifcation built in. It being quick to build was a bonus in the development process. It is the most replaceable part of this stack though, so whatever works for you.

This is the core of the admin interface, and the tool that enables the whole static architecture. It provides the easy interface for content authors, I found it extremely easy to get started. It runs as a client-side SPA, which is ideal. While I did find a few spots that need work, it does the basics well. The big alternative in the space is DecapCMS, which StaticCMS forked off of. The changes arenâ€™t huge, but theyâ€™re appreciated. Theyâ€™re things updating react, dropping backends Iâ€™m not using, and cleaning up options. The community also seems more active.

item.title: Crabs ðŸ¦€
item.description:
A play about crabs, coconuts, and bromance.

Crabs

div.p: A play about crabs, coconuts, and bromance.
Iâ€™m kinda proud of the effect. Itâ€™s pretty dumb, and could definitely induce motion sickness if you stare at it for too long. Butâ€¦â€‹ It looks cool.
Also, after far, far too long I am (just about) ready to say this site is at version 1.0. Hurrah.

There are 2 things to see here. Firstly, I set the content attribute to be equal to the title. Secondly and unrelatedly, I vary the font size to make the title take up a reasonable amount of the page.

span.span: font-size:{{ len .Title | math.Log | mul -7 | add 37 | math.Floor }}vmin

div.p: This is largely unremarkable, just a load of animation keyframes.

Do pay attention to the content and animation delay attributes though. content: attr(content) is the trick that allows me to easily set the overlay text to match. This is important because I can easily set html content on a per page basis with Hugo (the static site generator I use), but itâ€™s substantially harder to have unique CSS per page. animation-delay isnâ€™t useful for the majority of titles, but for the homepage I have each letter as its own separate animation. Iâ€™ve manually set a unique animation delay on each and that ensures the wandering clip paths donâ€™t all line up in an obvious way.

Iâ€™m currently rehearsing for Crossbow Cat, to be performed soon. Iâ€™m playing Cinnamon, who happens to be a cat. Cinnamon gained the ability to walk and talk when Martha shot her in the head with a crossbow, and now sheâ€™s back for revenge.

Itâ€™s been fascinating playing a cat, I was inspired by The Cat from Coraline and Cheshire Cat, but with more resentment. Cats are extremely mobile, and it turns out I love to move this way. The challenge of making myself look that mobile is interesting, thereâ€™s lots of lounging in odd positions, and pouncing on furniture. Itâ€™s as if a child was coordinated. Emotionally, Cinnamon needs therapy. Sheâ€™s a mess. Thereâ€™s a whole lot of anger at Martha for shooting her, resulting in her ostracisation from cat society, but below that thereâ€™s intense fear and loneliness. Cinnamon refuses to confront this though. She stalks and plans to kill Martha, but when goes to do it sheâ€™s so wildly off base. She brings knives, and doesnâ€™t even throw a punch. She is lost, and running from that towards an unquestioned goal. Sheâ€™s not going to let that stop her though. Cinnamon has a plan.
Weâ€™ll be performing from the 4th of September until the 8th at Studio 77 2021.
